title: 104_hr2594
content: The Act may be cited as the "Railroad Unemployment Insurance Amendments Act of 1996". It includes a waiting period for unemployment benefits. The Railroad Unemployment Insurance Act is amended to specify the payment of unemployment benefits, including a waiting period for the first registration period. The Railroad Unemployment Insurance Act specifies a waiting period for the initial period of continuing unemployment, including provisions for strikes and payment of benefits. The Railroad Unemployment Insurance Act specifies a waiting period for the initial period of continuing unemployment, including provisions for strikes and payment of benefits. If a period of continuing unemployment ends due to a specific reason but the work stoppage continues, a waiting period will apply to the employee's first registration period in a new period of continuing unemployment. The term 'period of continuing unemployment' is defined as a single registration period with more than 4 days of unemployment or a series of consecutive registration periods with more than 4 days of unemployment. The term 'period of continuing unemployment' is defined as a single registration period or consecutive periods with more than 4 days of unemployment. It ends when rights to benefits are exhausted, and no benefits are payable after that. An employee exhausts unemployment benefits when remuneration exceeds base year compensation. SEC. 3. WAITING PERIOD FOR SICKNESS BENEFITS. Amendment to the Railroad Unemployment Insurance Act regarding the payment of sickness benefits after the 4th consecutive day of sickness in a period of continuing sickness. Benefits are payable for each day of sickness in excess of 7 during the employee's first registration period in a period of continuing sickness. The definition of a period of continuing sickness includes consecutive days of sickness from one or more causes or successive days of sickness due to a single cause without interruption of more than 90 consecutive days which are not days of sickness. The definition of a period of continuing sickness includes consecutive days of sickness from one or more causes or successive days of sickness due to a single cause without interruption of more than 90 consecutive days which are not days of sickness. A period of continuing sickness ends when an employee exhausts rights to sickness benefits under subsection (c) of this section. SEC. 4. MAXIMUM DAILY BENEFIT RATE amended to calculate benefits based on monthly compensation. SEC. 5. MAXIMUM NUMBER OF DAYS FOR BENEFITS specified. The Railroad Unemployment Insurance Act is amended to set a maximum of 130 days for unemployment and sickness benefits within a benefit year, with the total benefits not exceeding the employee's compensation in the base year. The Railroad Unemployment Insurance Act limits benefits to 130 days per year, with total benefits not exceeding the employee's compensation in the base year. The Railroad Unemployment Insurance Act limits benefits to 130 days per year, with total benefits not exceeding the employee's compensation in the base year. Extended benefits are available for employees with 10 or more years of service who exhaust their normal benefits for days of unemployment or sickness. Extended benefits can be paid for up to 65 days of unemployment or sickness after normal benefits are exhausted. The extended benefit period begins on the first day of unemployment or sickness and lasts for 7 consecutive 14-day periods. Extended benefits can be paid for up to 65 days of unemployment or sickness after normal benefits are exhausted, lasting for 7 consecutive 14-day periods. The extended benefit period terminates when the employee reaches age 65. The extended benefit period for sickness benefits ends when the employee turns 65, but can continue for paying benefits for days of unemployment. Employees with 10 or more years of service and 14 or more consecutive days of unemployment or sickness may qualify for accelerated benefits. The extended benefit period for sickness benefits ends at age 65, but can continue for unemployment days. Employees with 10+ years of service and 14+ consecutive days of unemployment or sickness may qualify for accelerated benefits. The Railroad Unemployment Insurance Act provisions regarding sickness benefits ending at age 65, repeal of deadwood provision, and repeal of expired provision related to supplemental unemployment benefits. The amendments made by this Act will be effective on the date of enactment.
